headline: Bitcoin Surges Past $93K as Risk Appetite Returns

sections.the_session:
• Bitcoin pushed decisively through the $93,000 level during European hours, consolidating gains that began in Asian trading — the move carries more conviction than recent attempts, with spot volumes running 40% above the 30-day average.

• Ethereum's 8.6% surge outpaced Bitcoin by a comfortable margin, narrowing the performance gap that had widened through April — ETH reclaiming $3,380 suggests rotation into higher-beta assets as risk appetite firms.

• The Fear & Greed Index climbed to 67, its highest reading in three weeks, though liquidation data tells a more nuanced story: $180 million in shorts were swept during the rally, but long positions remain relatively modest.

• Solana's 5.7% gain kept pace with the broader market, though trading activity on its DEXs actually declined — a divergence worth watching as price and usage metrics rarely stay disconnected for long.
sections.the_session_title: Bitcoin Reclaims Ground, Ethereum Leads the Charge
sections.the_macro:
• US spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded $287 million in net inflows on Monday, the strongest single day since mid-April — BlackRock's IBIT accounted for roughly two-thirds of the total, suggesting institutional rather than retail demand.

• Federal Reserve officials maintained their patient stance on rate cuts, with Governor Waller noting inflation data needs "several more months" of improvement — crypto markets appeared to shrug off the hawkish undertone, focusing instead on the absence of further tightening signals.

• The dollar index softened 0.3% against a basket of major currencies, providing a tailwind for risk assets — Bitcoin's inverse correlation with DXY has reasserted itself after a period of decoupling.

• Treasury yields edged lower across the curve, with the 10-year settling at 4.42%, as markets digested a relatively light economic calendar ahead of Wednesday's GDP revision.
sections.the_macro_title: Fed Patience and ETF Flows Set the Tone

the_region.title: What Moved in Europe, Middle East & Africa

europe.name: Europe
europe.content:
• The European Central Bank's June rate cut remains firmly priced in, but today's comments from board member Isabel Schnabel emphasising "data dependence" introduced a note of caution — euro-denominated stablecoin volumes ticked higher on Kraken and Bitstamp as traders positioned for potential volatility.

• Germany's BaFin approved a second crypto custody licence this month, this time for Stuttgart-based Bankhaus Scheich — the steady drip of institutional infrastructure suggests MiCA's harmonised framework is beginning to unlock previously hesitant capital.

• Circle's EURC stablecoin saw its largest single-day minting since launch, with €45 million issued through a Paris-based OTC desk — the identity of the buyer remains undisclosed, though the size points to institutional rather than retail demand.

• The UK's FCA published updated guidance on crypto financial promotions, clarifying that offshore exchanges targeting British consumers face enforcement action regardless of domicile — several smaller platforms have already begun geo-blocking UK IP addresses in response.

middle_east.name: Middle East
middle_east.content:
• Dubai's VARA granted a full operational licence to OKX, making it the fourth major exchange to secure unrestricted status in the emirate — the approval allows OKX to offer derivatives products, a category VARA had previously approached with caution.

• Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund ADQ disclosed a "strategic exploration" of blockchain infrastructure investments in its latest annual report, though specific allocations remain undisclosed — the language marks a notable shift from last year's silence on digital assets.

• Bahrain's central bank issued draft rules for algorithmic stablecoins, becoming the first Gulf regulator to distinguish them from fiat-backed alternatives — the framework would require algorithmic issuers to maintain a 150% collateral buffer, effectively a hybrid model.

• Saudi Arabia's NEOM project confirmed it is evaluating blockchain-based payment rails for the planned city's internal economy, according to documents reviewed by regional media — no timeline or technology partner has been announced.

africa.name: Africa
africa.content:
• Nigeria's Securities and Exchange Commission announced it will begin accepting licence applications from crypto exchanges on June 1, ending months of regulatory limbo — the framework requires local incorporation and naira liquidity reserves, conditions that may prove challenging for global platforms.

• South Africa's FSCA confirmed that 63 crypto asset service providers have now received full licences under the country's new regime, with another 120 applications pending — the regulator noted that several applicants withdrew rather than meet enhanced AML requirements.

• Kenya's largest mobile money provider M-Pesa is piloting a stablecoin off-ramp with a Nairobi-based fintech, allowing users to convert USDC to mobile money balances — the trial is limited to 5,000 users but represents a significant bridge between crypto rails and Africa's dominant payment infrastructure.

• Ethiopian authorities seized mining equipment at a warehouse near Addis Ababa, citing unlicensed electricity consumption — the operation reportedly drew 2.5 megawatts from the grid, highlighting the tension between cheap hydropower and regulatory oversight.

sections.the_region_title: What Moved in Europe, Middle East & Africa

image_keywords: Canary Wharf, golden sunset, Thames, warm evening glow
